lines: A neighbor approaches you and asks if you would like to make some extra money doing yard work. You evaluate the job: It is back-breaking work for a $10.00 per week payoff.

After your third week of work, your friends plan a trip to the mall and ask if you would like to come along. Jamie's mother will be driving, but the trip will occur during the time when you usually do the yard work. There is no way you
can squeeze the two events in on the same day, and still do a good job on the lawn. You can:
#DO A QUICK JOB ON THE LAWN AND HOPE NOBODY NOTICES
#ASK YOUR NEIGHBOR IF HE WOULD MIND NOT HAVING HIS LAWN DONE
You stay and do your yard work like a responsible person. At this point, how much money are you putting away in the bank every week?

You lack the self-control to do any real saving. Like most children, you are quick to dip into your savings for little pleasures. You have, however, shown good attitudes toward responsibility, which will help you with work later on.
Your savings habits are admirable. You will accumulate $400 that you will bring with you into the next module.
Somebody DOES notice, and as a result spends the rest of the afternoon finishing the job you started. You are fired from your first job after three short weeks.
He doesn't mind. He simply asks your best friend who is happy to take the job and the money. He does a much better job on the lawn and gets the job full time. You are replaced.
He asks the boy down the block who does a much better job and is willing to take $9.00. You are replaced.
Work is not for you right now. That's O.K., but you have just passed up an opportunity to collect some resources.
